body:
Gregory J. Ward wrote:


> Umm...  this is the first mention of Sourceforge.  Other than the
> dozens of mirror sites and mass confusion that results, is there any
> advantage to going this route?  Would we lose the nice CVS source
> tree access Peter's set up at <http://www.radiance-online.org/cgi-bin/
> viewcvs.cgi/>?  I have no problem with read-only CVS access, though I
> don't find the system terribly convenient, myself.




The advantage is that we'll get the same functionality as we have
now (and much more), just without the administrative overhead.
Nobody will get confused if they try to download a file and are
offered a selection of sources to get it from. It's just one more
click.


I don't see LBNL installing, running, continuously updating, and
administrating a public CVS server, and I am certainly not in a
position to do it myself. Since nobody has presented a workable
alternative so far, there is no choice but to use Sourceforge or
a similar service. Francesco has suggested Savannah, which seems
to be something similar, although with much less functionality.
It might still be sufficient for what we need, though.


There are a few other (usually smaller) sites that do similar
things. I have only worked with Sourceforge myself, so I don't
know how well the others work. Obviously, Sourceforge will catch
the most flak when something goes wrong, simply because of their
large number of users. On the other hand, thousands of projects
are still quite happy with them, especially now that the CVS and
mailing list services have been upgraded.




But the most urgent question is what happens with the domain.
If we get too close to the expiry date, then Netsol will block
any transfer attempts until after the next period has been paid
for. Since Netsol is one of the most expensive registrars, we
probably don't want that to happen. So whoever gets assigned as
the future host of radiance-online.org should initiate the domain
transfer immediately. After that we still have time to figure out
all the other details.
